Variation Example: In a land where the use of the sickle is unknown, grain is picked or shot down with guns. When the people try to use a sickle, it cuts one of the men. People think the sickle is a dangerous animal & drown it as punishment.

Classifications: The Scythe Cuts a Man's Head Off
Variation Example: A numskull carries a scythe (sickle) around his neck. When he tries to take it off, he cuts his head off.

Classifications: The Sickle Thought to be a Serpent
Variation Example: Numskulls find a sickle & mistake it for a serpent (worm, dragon, monster). They strike it & it bounces up & lands around the neck of one of them. When they pull on the “serpent”, they cut off the man’s head.
Fool Keeps Repeating His Instructions so as to remember them. He usually forgets them.

This misc. type includes tales in which a fool misunderstands the nature of domestic animals. For example, an (old) woman tries to milk a hen, or she insults (slays) it because it does not suckle its chicks.
A bell is tied on a salmon (eel, pike) so that the fish can be found later.

Classifications: Cow is Taken to the Roof to Graze
Variation Example: In some variants, the animal is driven up a ramp; in others it is hoisted up to the roof or a (church-) tower & strangled.

A farmwife (numskull) kills the cow (goat, ox) because she thinks it is mimicking her (will not give her any chewing gum). In some variants, an animal is killed because its lowing (bleating, or the like) is misinterpreted as laughter or mockery. In other variants, a villager believes that the donkey listens to what he tells him, because its ear move.

Fools build an enclosure of hedges to hold a cuckoo. It flies over one of the hedges. They say that they have not built the walls high enough In some variants, a numskull decides to close the town gate so that a bird (e.g. falcon, dove) that flew away cannot escape.
An auctioneer (salesman) praises a man’s worthless cow so much that the man takes it back himself.

Classifications: Driving a Horse into Its Bridle
Variation Example: Driving a Horse into Its Collar (Bridle) instead of putting it on the horse.

Classifications: The Miller, His Son, & the Donkey
Variation Example: (Asinus vulgi.) A miller & his son travel with one donkey (horse). First the son rides & is rebuked by a passerby for letting his father walk. Then the father rides & is criticized because he makes his son walk. When both ride or both walk, they are still blamed. As a lesson, the father shows the son that it is difficult (impossible) to please every one. In some variants, at the end the father & son carry the donkey (horse) between them & throw it into the water, or kill it.
It was written in chalk on door & washed off by rain.

Classifications: Numskull Sits on Eggs to Finish Hatching
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A stupid son (a foolish husband) stays alone at home. Among other things, he is responsible for a brooding hen (goose), but bungles the task: The bird is disturbed & runs away (the numskull kills it). Because he is afraid of his mother (wife), he sits on the eggs himself to finish the hatching (sometimes covers himself with honey or tar & feathers before sitting on the eggs). (2) A rogue undertakes the strenuous job of hatching eggs for which he is to be well paid. When the employer (e.g. lady of the manor) asks for the results, he burns down the barn with the osten-sibly hatched chickens & pretends that they all have died. (3) A rogue induces someone to sit on eggs in order to put him in a humiliating position.

Classifications: The Fish Too Large for the Pan
Variation Example: Fools (numskulls) throw away a fish (cake) because it is too large for the pan. Or they shorten a ladder because it is too long to carry between trees.

A rogue’s (numskull’s) head is cut off by accident (bitten off by a bear, wolf, or crocodile while hunting, torn off in a mill, smashed off by a rock, caught in tree branches). His compan-ions find the corpse without a head & debate: Did he ever have a head?. They remember only his beard. His wife knows that she once knitted a cap for him (that the barber often came to shave him), & he therefore must have had a head.

Classifications: How Did the Cow Get on the Pole?
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two dif fer ent forms: (1) A student (often the son of a farmer) comes home from the university for a visit. Lying in bed, he wonders how cow-dung could get on the roof. His father informs him that the beam was already dirty when it was installed. (2) (On advice of a rascal) a fool (fools) hide(s) a purse on top of a pole (in a nest on a high tree). The rascal substitutes dry cow-dung for the money. The fool is interested only in how the cow could have climbed the pole.

Two numskulls (men or women) plan to catch a squirrel. One pursues it while the other runs back home to get a pan (a pot). The first falls from a tree (and is killed). The face of the first is covered with blood from the fall & the second thinks that his companion has eaten the raw squirrel & choked on it. Full of anger, he breaks the pot (on his head).

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A fool looks down the barrel as a gun is fired (2) Two fools mistake a gun for a flute. They decide that one will blow it while the other will press the “keys”. The gun goes off & shoots off the head of the “flutist”. (3) Fools fire a wooden gun which explodes & kills several of them. They rejoice that the enemy has suffered an even greater loss.

Trickster & companion go wolf (bear) hunting. One slips into the wolf’s den. When the wolf returns, the man outside catches him by the tail. The wolf scratches the earth so that dust gets into the companion’s eyes. “What a lot of dust.” – “If the wolf’s tail breaks, you will see quite another kind of dust!”. In some variants, the trickster in the den asks, “Why is it so dark in here?” – “If the tail breaks, you will know.”
Numskulls try to shovel nuts with a pitchfork. A stranger shows them how to do this work more easily with a shovel (a basket). (He gets a large reward.)

A woman on a pilgrimage accidentally disarranges her skirt (and shirt), exposing her naked buttocks. Her husband does not say anything to her about this because he thinks this is part of her pilgrimage vow.

Classifications: Rebuke for Going with Naked Head
Variation Example: A woman, having been criticized for walking in the street with her head uncovered, covers it with her skirt & thus exposes her buttocks.
Seven (nine) men plan to attack the fierce animal. One of them screams from fear & the animal runs away.

Classifications: The Roof in Good & Bad Weather
Variation Example: A man does not build a roof on his house (does not repair it): He does not need a roof when the weather is fair; & he cannot put one on in the rain.
A fool sitting on a branch of a tree cuts it off. In a Greek version, he climbs with difficulty onto a dead branch of a tree, which breaks off.

Classifications: The Tree is to be Pulled Down
Variation Example: Fools (numskulls) pity a tree (usually a willow) that stands near a pond & hangs its branches down as if it wants to drink. They pull it down in order to give it water. One man sticks his head in the branches while the others pull on his legs. In some variants, they tear his head off, in others, they all fall down.

Numskulls (a fool & his donkey) try to pull out a tree that stands on a cliff. The tree falls & drags them down with it. In some variants, fools fell a tree so that it will fall directly onto a wagon. The tree breaks the wagon & kills the horse (the ox).

A fool loads wood piece by piece into a wagon saying, “If the horses (oxen) can pull this, they can pull one more piece”. When he finally finds that they are unable to pull the load, he throws off piece after piece, reasoning, “If they cannot pull this, they cannot pull one less”. He drives home with an empty wagon. (In some Finnish variants, the foolish person is female.

Instead of placing a sack of flour (some other load) on the donkey’s (ox’s) back, a rider puts it on his shoulder to relieve the animal of its burden. In some variants a man puts a load on one side of a saddle & balances it on the other side with a rock.

Classifications: Wood is Carried Down the Hill
Variation Example: Fools carry a heavy tree trunk (millstone) down a hill. On the way, they drop the trunk & it rolls the rest of the way down. When they notice that the job is much easier this way, they carry the trunk back up the hill in order to roll it down again.
Fools are given a beam (pole, footbridge, bench) which is too short. They try in different ways to stretch the beam. Of course they do not succeed, but in a German variant they think they do.

Classifications: Sunlight carried in a bag into the windowless house
Variation Example: Fools collect sunlight in a sack (basket, sieve) & try to carry it into a windowless house. When this plan does not succeed, fools gradually pull down the house in order to get light. (A stranger shows them how to make a window.) In some variants, fools use a white sheepskin as a source of light or try to catch light in a mouse trap. Similarly, fools carry out smoke in a sieve.

A fool lets his axe fall. The other people think that this was intentional & throw theirs into the same place. This short episode is usually followed by a second one, in which the fools try to cut down trees in different ways: (1) By burning them down: In order to get fire, one fool beats another’s head so that the latter will see sparks. (2) By pulling them out: One fool sticks his head in the branches, the others pull & tear his head off.

Classifications: The Man Sticks His Head into the Hole of the Millstone
Variation Example: Fools want to roll a millstone down a hill. One of them sticks his head into the hole of the millstone in order to lead it (to see where it rolls). It rolls into a lake. The fool’s head is torn off.

Classifications: Tree-Trunks Laid Crosswise on a Sledge
Variation Example: Fools want to trans-port a stack of wood (a long tree-trunk). They lay it crosswise on a sledge (a wagon) & cannot get out of the forest (through a gate). Only when they see a bird passing by carrying a blade of straw side-ways do find the solution for their problem.

Fools want to measure the depth of a well (retrieve something from the water). They lay a log across its top. One man holds the log with his hands, the next climbs down & holds his feet, & so on. The uppermost man becomes tired & lets go to spit in his hands. All fall into the well. In some variants, the human chain is built in order to reach the top of a tree. In an Indian/Sri Lankan version, the human chain (a chain of monkeys) dangles from the tail of a flying elephant.

Classifications: Hampers Pilled Up to Measure Tower
Variation Example: Fools place baskets one on top of the other in order to measure the height of a tower. The one at the bottom is removed & all fall. In some variants numskulls want to reach a bird’s nest (an animal’s den) in a high tree. They climb on each other’s shoulders. When the fool at the bottom falls down, all the others fall too.

Classifications: A Hole to Throw the Earth In
Variation Example: Numskull(s) plan(s) to dig a hole so as to have a place to throw the soil from his excavations.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Numskulls put flour (rolled oats) into the bubbling current of an ice hole & then, one after another, jump in to taste the porridge. They die. (2) Numskulls buy a kettle that is supposed to boil by itself. It does not work so & they throw it into the water. As the kettle sinks down it sends up bubbles. Thinking that the kettle is finally boiling, the numskulls jump into the water to retrieve it. (3) A woman puts flour in a river (sugar in a well) in order to make dough for bread (lemonade). She loses it all (and her husband throws her out).
